course_title: Indigenous Languages: Understanding Language Descriptions for Access and Use

learning_outcomes.description: Critically engage with and contribute to current discussions on language and collections management and access, Indigenous Cultural and Intellectual Property rights and the opportunities and challenges presented by digital technologies.
Apply linguistic frameworks and terminology to analyse Indigenous languages.

Identify and analyse cultural meanings embedded in language features, recognizing the inseparable connection between language, culture, and identity and apply this to enrich language description and revitalisation practices.
Repurpose and share specialist language knowledge with a range of audiences and for diverse purposes.

assessments.task_description:
This assessment consists of three problem sets on the following topics.

  • Nouns
  • Verbs
  • Syntax

A 30-minute block will be allocated during the workshop for each set. Each problem set is marked out of 10 points.

assessments.task_description:
In this assessment, you will select an archival or published language resource to critically evaluate and write a report that:

  • introduces the context of your resource in general terms, e.g., situating it in terms of language group, location, people, personal experience and/or material discussed in class
  • describes the key aspects of a language resource or an archival object including author/s, speaker/s, format, location held, archival status, etc.
  • describes the intended purpose of the language resource or archival object
  • critically evaluates strengths and weaknesses of the resource using criteria of discoverability, accessibility, use and reliability
  • connects your evaluation to the readings and other class materials on the topic
  • demonstrates independent research, critical reading, synthesis and structuring

Expected length of the report is approximately 1200 words (no longer than 1500).

Proposed structure and style of your report will be discussed in class.

Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. assessments.assessment_title: Own Language Description and Resource Creation
assessments.task_description:
This assessment involves creating a language resource. You must design it for a specific purpose, identifying a strategy to distribute it and reflecting on how it meets the intended purpose. The resource may be in print, digital, video or other format as negotiated with the lecturer. The resource must apply aspects of language description (e.g. sounds, spelling, word classes, suffixes, phrases, sentence structure, cultural meanings embedded in language, etc.).

The assignment will include a copy of the resource itself and a commentary, which must include:

  1. An overview explaining the intended context, audience and purpose of the resource.
  2. A plan for a distribution and archiving strategy appropriate to the resource and your context.
  3. A critical reflection that evaluates the strengths and weaknesses of your resource in meeting its intended purpose.

Commentary word length 1200 words =/- 10%

assessments.task_description:
Task Description – Language learning is an on-going journey. This assessment is designed to encourage you to dedicate some time to your own language learning. For this task you should practice language weekly and write a weekly journal entry, for four weeks from 27th October to 22th November.

In this course, you are learning about linguistic concepts and methods. This might inform the focus for your language learning. You may align your language learning to the language resource you create for task 3.

The length guide per entry is 200 words (+/- 10%). Your entry should include:

Include descriptions of:

  • your language learning goals
  • language materials you accessed
  • an aspect of your language, using a combination of plain language and linguistic terminology
  • language learning strategies you have tried

Reflect on your above descriptions to include:

  • new learnings about your language
  • reflections on your engagement with people or resources
  • helpful and unhelpful strategies or ideas
  • ideas for future language learning pathways
  • links between theory or readings and real-life situations

Word limit for your journal is 200 words per entry, and a total of 800 words +/- %10.

learning_activities.topic:
Pre-Workshop On-line Session 1

Guest talk by Dr Lesley Woods. Indigenous Linguistics. Accessible language description: Issues and solutions

A proud Ngiyampaa Wangaaypuwan woman, Lesley holds a PhD in Linguistics from the Australian National University. She brings more than 20 years of experience working ethically and collaboratively with Aboriginal communities across New South Wales and Western Australia. Lesley’s work is grounded in a strong commitment to linguistic justice for First Nations peoples. 

Lesley is Regional Coordinator and Linguist at Muurrbay Aboriginal Language and Culture Co-operative. She oversees support for seven coastal Aboriginal languages and works closely with communities to provide expert linguistic guidance, develop and deliver language courses, and offer support to enhance language revitalisation efforts.

Intensive Day 1

Monday – Session 1

People and Languages in the room

Getting going on linguistic description

  • Decolonising Linguistics: Language materials and language descriptions – purposes, authors, audiences
  • Exploring grammar in communication and language functions

Monday – Session 2

Guest talk: Katie Jepson

Phonology – Sounds and spelling

  • Describing and comparing sounds across languages
  • looking at sounds in combinations and in natural speech

More language functions - phrases for everyday communication and what they tell us about the structure of language

Monday – Session 3

Investigating ways that culture is embedded in language

  • pronoun systems
  • semantics, metaphorics and meaning extension

Assignment planning: Own Language Description and Resource Creation (Task 3)

learning_activities.topic:
Intensive Day 2

Tuesday – Sessions 1 & 2

Describing Language with technical linguistic terminology

  • Names, nouns and associated classes in Indigenous Languages
  • Word-building, exploring morphology

Tuesday – Session 3

Guest talk by Dr Rose Barrowcliffe on best practice in representation and access to archives and frameworks for Indigenous records, materials and collections, including Indigenous Cultural and Intellectual Property (ICIP) rights.

Rose Barrowcliffe is a Butchulla woman, a post-doctoral research fellow at Macquarie University and a chief investigator for the Language Data Commons of Australia Australia. Rose’s research examines the representation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in archives and on embedding Indigenous perspectives in metadata to support discoverability and access of records for Indigenous peoples.

Time on assignments - Case study of a language resource (Task 2)
